lines.code: # German inflection of depends on gender, role and number + the determiner (if any).

lines.code: # Masculine is the most common, so it is the default for all functions.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # - nom = subject, "Der Hund bellt" (the dog barks).
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # - acc = object, "Das Mädchen küsst den Hund" (the girl kisses the dog).
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # - dat = object (indirect), "Der Mann gibt einen Knochen zum Hund" (the man gives the dog a bone).
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # - gen = property, "die Knochen des Hundes" (the dog's bone).
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: NOMINATIVE, ACCUSATIVE, DATIVE, GENITIVE = SUBJECT, OBJECT, INDIRECT, PROPERTY = \
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: """ Returns the base form of the given inflected verb, using a rule-based approach.

lines.code: # Common prefixes: be-finden and emp-finden probably inflect like finden.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: if not (v.startswith("ge") and v.endswith("t")): # Probably gerund.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: if v.startswith(prefix) and v[len(prefix):] in self.inflections:
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: b, suffix = " " in v and v.split()[:2] or  (v, "")

lines.code: if b.endswith(x): b = b[:-len(x)] + y; break

lines.code: if not b.endswith(("e", "l")) and not (b.endswith("er") and len(b) >= 3 and not b[-3] in VOWELS):
lines.author: markus.beuckelmann@web.de

lines.code: """ For a regular verb (base form), returns the forms using a rule-based approach.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: b = b0 = re.sub("en$", "", re.sub("ln$", "l", re.sub("rn$", "r", v)))
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Present tense 1sg and subjunctive -el: handeln => ich handle, du handlest.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: pl = b.endswith("el") and b[:-2]+"l" or b
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: pw = v.endswith(("ln", "rn")) and v or b+"en"
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Present tense ending in -d or -t gets -e:
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: pr = b.endswith(("d", "t")) and b+"e" or b
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Present tense 2sg gets -st, unless stem ends with -s or -z.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: p2 = pr.endswith(("s","z")) and pr+"t" or pr+"st"
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: pp = v.endswith(("en", "ln", "rn")) and v+"d" or v+"end"
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: ge = (v.startswith(prefix_inseparable) or b.endswith(("r","t"))) and pt or "ge"+pt
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: ge = x and x+"ge"+pt or ge
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: pl+"e"+x1, p2+x1, pr+"t"+x1, pw+x1, pr+"t"+x1, pp,             # present
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: pt+"e"+x1, pt+"est"+x1, pt+"e"+x1, pt+"en"+x1, pt+"et"+x1, ge, # past
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: s1+"e"+x1, s1+"est"+x1, s1+"en"+x1, s1+"et"+x1,                # subjunctive I
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: s2+"e"+x1, s2+"est"+x1, s2+"en"+x1, s2+"et"+x1                 # subjunctive II
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Encode Eszett (ß) and attempt to retrieve from the lexicon.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Decode Eszett for present and imperative.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: a = [decode_sz(v) for v in a[:7]] + a[7:13] + [decode_sz(v) for v in a[13:20]] + a[20:]
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Since the lexicon does not contain imperative for all verbs, don't simply return it.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: # Instead, update the rule-based lexeme with inflections from the lexicon.
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: return [a[i] or lexeme[i] for i in range(len(a))]
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: """ For a predicative adjective, returns the attributive form (lowercase).

lines.code: In German, the attributive is formed with -e, -em, -en, -er or -es,
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: depending on gender (masculine, feminine, neuter or plural) and role
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: adjective.lower(), gender[:1].lower(), role[:3].lower(), article and article.lower() or None
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: In German, the attributive form preceding a noun is always used:
lines.author: tom@organisms.be

lines.code: The predicative is useful for lemmatization.
